content.content: Patient Assessment is an organized process for gathering concise and accurate information about a patient. It consists of four components. This patient assessment model is the standard in pre-hospital care. Follow steps 1–4 in order.

Standard Precautions is part of Scene Size-Up and is designed to protect rescuers and patients from becoming infected with blood-borne pathogens as well as viruses and bacteria through contact and droplet transmission.

Hand hygiene (e.g., hand washing or hand sanitizer) is the most effective precaution easily implemented in the backcountry to prevent transmission of a range of infections from the common cold to more serious ones like the Norwalk virus or hepatitis A (HAV).

Contact transmission occurs via skin-to-skin contact with an open wound and with items that an infected person has touched (e.g., methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), herpes simplex virus (cold sores), conjunctivitis (pink eye), and hepatitis A (HAV)).
Droplet transmission occurs when pathogens are transmitted through air droplets by coughing, sneezing, or talking (e.g., common cold, influenza, laryngitis, SARS-CoV2, and bacterial meningitis).

Blood-borne transmission occurs when blood or body fluid from an infected person enters another person’s body via sex, needle-sticks, human bites, cuts, abrasions, or through mucous membranes (e.g., the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), hepatitis B virus (HBV), and hepatitis C virus (HCV)).
Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is the standard of care when treating patients in a wilderness setting:

items: 1. Gloves: Required anytime there is contact with mucous membranes, non-intact skin, blood, or any other body fluids of patients...
2. Protective Surgical Masks: Required for rescuers and patients anytime a pathogen is transmittable via droplets.
3. CPR Mask (pocket mask): Required anytime CPR or rescue breathing is performed on patients to protect rescuers from body fluids.
4. Eye Protection: Glasses or sunglasses help protect against disease transmission from body fluids splashing into mucous membranes of the rescuer’s eyes via droplet transmission.
5. Clothing: In the event of significant blood splashes, as with major bleeding, protective clothing such as a rain jacket and rain pants can be used to avoid rescuer contamination.

content.content: Disposal of Contaminated Equipment and Waste

Contaminated clothing, gear and waste should be isolated in a designated, non-permeable bag. Used needles, referred to as “sharps,” should be sealed in a hard container that will inhibit the sharp end of the needle from poking out and potentially contaminating another person.

content.content: Understand the four sections of patient assessment and apply the model to all medical and trauma patients.

items: 1. Understand why Scene Size-Up is so important for the safety of the rescuers, the group and the injured person(s).
2. Identify the common life threats for ABCDEG within the Primary Assessment.
3. Identify if the patient is critical or stable based on their injuries upon completion of the Primary Assessment.
4. Make an informed transport/evacuation decision after the Primary Assessment.
